file_content.text: We are packing our bags. We will be gone with the light.
Thank you for your kindness.
Even here, we find no true refuge.
Hold.
We have no more with which to defend ourselves. You have left us helpless before the rakghouls and everything that haunts this planet.
My people are refugees, survivors of the battle on Coruscant. Would you turn us out of yet another home?
The owners have been waiting for centuries to return here.
This land belongs to someone.
Who are you?
My name is Achitan, and you might call me the leader of this colony. We fled here after the war.
The lower levels were in shambles, thousands of people from thousands of species homeless and hurt. The humans in the Galactic Senate barely slapped on a new coat of paint.
We came here to start a new life.
Unfortunately, your "new life" landed on someone else's ancient birthright.
Sad, but still a problem.
A horrific story.
I've got no use for squatters. Clear out before I get mad.
Get lost.
I don't care where you go, as long as you're not my problem.
Yes.
It is clear I cannot stand before all of you, but may I take just a moment more to try to sway your hearts?
You must face the same human prejudice as us! I'm surprised to see you so callous.
How typically human.
So many men are here to reclaim this planet who know nothing of its past.
Ancient Taris was a blight on the Republic, the black mark on its reputation for freedom.
As far as I know, it was some Outer Rim nothing until the Empire blew it up.
What are you talking about?
Humans on Taris did as they do on all planets. They seized the surface, claimed Taris's wealth and forced every other species underground.
Every meter of land owned by a human was probably seized from another species, just as this was seized from my ancestors.
Skip the history lesson.
It is more than history when we still bleed for it today.
You need somewhere to settle, I'm sure there's unclaimed land.
Let's talk compromise.
This is my land. My ancestors owned it for generations before the humans on Taris exiled them and all other species belowground.
I have their documents, so old they were kept in printed form. Read them yourself if you doubt me.
Every person should be judged on their own merit.
A sorry history.
The Jedi Order has always understood that.
Your kind has contributed many Masters who are strong in the Force.
Your rights deserve respect.
We connect to the Force through our ties to our homes.
The Republic must have had reasons for supporting such measures.
It was a long time ago.
What "reason" can deprive millions of their homes and drive them underground?
If this place is valuable, you won't find any shortage of folks willing to steal and kill for it.
Documents can be forged.
My people have a saying, "Credits bear no children." It is lives that matter, not money.
If you have legal claim, why not bring it to the Republic?
Prove it.
They prefer not to admit Taris's ugly history.
Still, we came to start over. I had hoped the new Taris would not be so quickly tainted by the old.
What happened? There must have been a reason.
Tell me more about Taris.
It was about money, of course. A human governor cut taxes to favor his people, and when others rebelled, they were the ones punished.
I think the claim was "aliens are dangerous to Tarisian trade."
If you have any sympathy for our cause, perhaps there is something you can do? We are alone and at the Republic's mercy.
I would not wish to see you turned away from your home.
I'll make sure you can stay.
I thank you for softening your heart to my story.
I will tell my people to begin repairs on our droids.
I'll use small words: Be gone by tomorrow. You've seen what I can do.
Get out. Nobody cares.
You have already destroyed our defenses. I will risk no lives to defy you further.
Give me my papers, then, so I might at least try whatever avenues the Republic opens to me.
Here they are. I wish you luck.
I hope you work something out.
Thank you, then, for that at least.
Giving them back will just encourage you.
Oh, no. These get destroyed.
No!
With that act, you have destroyed our lives.
Take them and good riddance.
I hope our paths have no more opportunity to cross.
When I saw who had come, I had hope. But you have proven yourself no better than a human.
I am sorry to see humans have changed so little in three hundred years.
What are you doing? Those are our only defenses!
Our colony can support no more settlers.
Your kind are not welcome here.
